kubernetes_controls.name: Access to host IPC namespace
kubernetes_controls.description: Sharing the host’s IPC namespace allows container processes to communicate with processes on the host.

kubernetes_controls.name: Access to host network
kubernetes_controls.description: Sharing the host’s network namespace permits processes in the pod to communicate with processes bound to the host’s loopback adapter.

kubernetes_controls.name: Access to host PID
kubernetes_controls.description: Sharing the host’s PID namespace allows visibility on host processes, potentially leaking information such as environment variables and configuration.

kubernetes_controls.name: Access to host ports
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard 'Host Ports', hostPorts should be disallowed, or at minimum restricted to a known list.

kubernetes_controls.name: Access to host process
kubernetes_controls.description: Windows hostprocess container permits processes in the pod to access the host's network interfaces and IP addresses

kubernetes_controls.name: All container images must start with a GCR domain
kubernetes_controls.description: Containers should only use images from trusted GCR registries.

kubernetes_controls.name: All container images must start with an ECR domain
kubernetes_controls.description: Containers should only use images from trusted registries.

kubernetes_controls.name: All container images must start with the *.azurecr.io domain
kubernetes_controls.description: Containers should only use images from trusted registries.

kubernetes_controls.name: Anonymous user access binding
kubernetes_controls.description: Binding to anonymous user to any clusterrole or role is a security risk

kubernetes_controls.name: Can elevate its own privileges
kubernetes_controls.description: A program inside the container can elevate its own privileges and run as root, which might give the program control over the container and node.

kubernetes_controls.name: ConfigMap with secrets
kubernetes_controls.description: Storing secrets in configMaps is unsafe

kubernetes_controls.name: ConfigMap with sensitive content
kubernetes_controls.description: Storing sensitive content such as usernames and email addresses in configMaps is unsafe

kubernetes_controls.name: Container images from public registries used
kubernetes_controls.description: Container images must not start with an empty prefix or a defined public registry domain.

kubernetes_controls.name: CPU not limited
kubernetes_controls.description: Enforcing CPU limits prevents DoS via resource exhaustion.

kubernetes_controls.name: CPU requests not specified
kubernetes_controls.description: When containers have resource requests specified, the scheduler can make better decisions about which nodes to place pods on, and how to deal with resource contention.

kubernetes_controls.name: Default capabilities: some containers do not drop all
kubernetes_controls.description: The container should drop all default capabilities and add only those that are needed for its execution.

kubernetes_controls.name: Default capabilities: some containers do not drop any
kubernetes_controls.description: Security best practices require containers to run with minimal required capabilities.

kubernetes_controls.name: Default security context configured
kubernetes_controls.description: Security context controls the allocation of security parameters for the pod/container/volume, ensuring the appropriate level of protection. Relying on default security context may expose vulnerabilities to potential attacks that rely on privileged access.

kubernetes_controls.name: Delete pod logs
kubernetes_controls.description: Used to cover attacker’s tracks, but most clusters ship logs quickly off-cluster.

kubernetes_controls.name: Exec into Pods
kubernetes_controls.description: The ability to exec into a container with privileged access to the host or with an attached SA with higher RBAC permissions is a common escalation path to cluster-admin.

kubernetes_controls.name: hostPath volume mounted with docker.sock
kubernetes_controls.description: Mounting docker.sock from the host can give the container full root access to the host.

kubernetes_controls.name: hostPath volumes mounted
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard 'HostPath Volumes', HostPath volumes must be forbidden.

kubernetes_controls.name: Image tag ":latest" used
kubernetes_controls.description: It is best to avoid using the ':latest' image tag when deploying containers in production. Doing so makes it hard to track which version of the image is running, and hard to roll back the version.

kubernetes_controls.name: Kubernetes resource with disallowed volumes mounted
kubernetes_controls.description: HostPath present many security risks and as a security practice it is better to avoid critical host paths mounts.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage all resources
kubernetes_controls.description: Full control of the cluster resources, and therefore also “root” on all nodes where workloads can run and has access to all pods, secrets, and data.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage all resources at the namespace
kubernetes_controls.description: Full control of the resources within a namespace.  In some cluster configurations, this is excessive. In others, this is normal (a gitops deployment operator like flux)

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage configmaps
kubernetes_controls.description: Some workloads leverage configmaps to store sensitive data or configuration parameters that affect runtime behavior that can be modified by an attacker or combined with another issue to potentially lead to compromise.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage EKS IAM Auth ConfigMap
kubernetes_controls.description: Ability to add AWS IAM to RBAC bindings via special EKS configmap.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage Kubernetes networking
kubernetes_controls.description: The ability to control which pods get service traffic directed to them allows for interception attacks. Controlling network policy allows for bypassing lateral movement restrictions.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage Kubernetes RBAC resources
kubernetes_controls.description: An effective level of access equivalent to cluster-admin.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage Kubernetes workloads and pods
kubernetes_controls.description: Depending on the policies enforced by the admission controller, this permission ranges from the ability to steal compute (crypto) by running workloads or allowing for creating workloads that escape to the node as root and escalation to cluster-admin.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage namespace secrets
kubernetes_controls.description: Viewing secrets at the namespace scope can lead to escalation if another service account in that namespace has a higher privileged rolebinding or clusterrolebinding bound.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage secrets
kubernetes_controls.description: Viewing secrets at the cluster-scope is akin to cluster-admin in most clusters as there are typically at least one service accounts (their token stored in a secret) bound to cluster-admin directly or a role/clusterrole that gives similar permissions.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manages /etc/hosts
kubernetes_controls.description: Managing /etc/hosts aliases can prevent the container engine from modifying the file after a pod’s containers have already been started.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage webhookconfigurations
kubernetes_controls.description: Webhooks can silently intercept or actively mutate/block resources as they are being created or updated. This includes secrets and pod specs.

kubernetes_controls.name: Memory not limited
kubernetes_controls.description: Enforcing memory limits prevents DoS via resource exhaustion.

kubernetes_controls.name: Memory requests not specified
kubernetes_controls.description: When containers have memory requests specified, the scheduler can make better decisions about which nodes to place pods on, and how to deal with resource contention.

kubernetes_controls.name: NET_RAW capability added
kubernetes_controls.description: The NET_RAW capability grants attackers the ability to eavesdrop on network traffic or generate IP traffic with falsified source addresses, posing serious security risks.

kubernetes_controls.name: Non-core volume types used.
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard 'Volume types', non-core volume types must not be used.

kubernetes_controls.name: Non-default /proc masks set
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard '/proc Mount Type', the default /proc masks are set up to reduce attack surface, and should be required.

kubernetes_controls.name: Prevent binding to privileged ports
kubernetes_controls.description: The ports which are lower than 1024 receive and transmit various sensitive and privileged data. Allowing containers to use them can bring serious implications.

kubernetes_controls.name: Privileged
kubernetes_controls.description: Privileged containers share namespaces with the host system and do not offer any security. They should be used exclusively for system containers that require high privileges.

kubernetes_controls.name: PSS Restricted Mode
kubernetes_controls.description: Policy to enforce PSS.

kubernetes_controls.name: Root file system is not read-only
kubernetes_controls.description: An immutable root file system prevents applications from writing to their local disk. This can limit intrusions, as attackers will not be able to tamper with the file system or write foreign executables to disk.

kubernetes_controls.name: Runs as root user
kubernetes_controls.description: Force the running image to run as a non-root user to ensure least privileges.

kubernetes_controls.name: Runs with GID <= 10000
kubernetes_controls.description: Force the container to run with group ID > 10000 to avoid conflicts with the host’s user table.

kubernetes_controls.name: Runs with UID <= 10000
kubernetes_controls.description: Force the container to run with user ID > 10000 to avoid conflicts with the host’s user table.

kubernetes_controls.name: Runtime/Default AppArmor profile not set
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard 'AppArmor', the AppArmor key must be set to the runtime/default profile or to be undefined.

kubernetes_controls.name: Runtime/Default Seccomp profile not set
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard 'Seccomp', the RuntimeDefault seccomp profile must be required, or allow specific additional profiles.

kubernetes_controls.name: Seccomp policies disabled
kubernetes_controls.description: A program inside the container can bypass Seccomp protection policies.

kubernetes_controls.name: SELinux custom options set
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard 'SElinux', setting custom SELinux options should be disallowed.

kubernetes_controls.name: Service with External IP
kubernetes_controls.description: Services with external IP addresses allows direct access from the internet and might expose risk for CVE-2020-8554

kubernetes_controls.name: Specific capabilities added
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard 'Capabilities', capabilities beyond the default set must not be added.

kubernetes_controls.name: SYS_ADMIN capability added
kubernetes_controls.description: SYS_ADMIN gives the processes running inside the container privileges that are equivalent to root.

kubernetes_controls.name: SYS_MODULE capability added
kubernetes_controls.description: The SYS_MODULE capability grants attackers the ability to install and remove kernel modules, posing serious security risks.

kubernetes_controls.name: Unsafe sysctl options set
kubernetes_controls.description: Sysctls can disable security mechanisms or affect all containers on a host, and should be disallowed except for an allowed 'safe' subset. A sysctl is considered safe if it is namespaced in the container or the pod, and is isolated from other pods and processes on the same node.

kubernetes_controls.name: User with admin access
kubernetes_controls.description: Either cluster-admin or those granted powerful permissions.

kubernetes_controls.name: Workloads in the default namespace
kubernetes_controls.description: Checks whether a workload is running in the default namespace.

image_assurance.name: Non-workload-resources
image_assurance.description: Recommended policy for Kubernetes non-workloads resources
image_assurance.author: system

kubernetes_controls.description: Either cluster-admin or those granted powerful permissions.

kubernetes_controls.name: Workloads in the default namespace
kubernetes_controls.description: Checks whether a workload is running in the default namespace.

kubernetes_controls.name: Access to host IPC namespace
kubernetes_controls.description: Sharing the host’s IPC namespace allows container processes to communicate with processes on the host.

kubernetes_controls.name: Access to host network
kubernetes_controls.description: Sharing the host’s network namespace permits processes in the pod to communicate with processes bound to the host’s loopback adapter.

kubernetes_controls.name: Access to host PID
kubernetes_controls.description: Sharing the host’s PID namespace allows visibility on host processes, potentially leaking information such as environment variables and configuration.

kubernetes_controls.name: Access to host ports
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard 'Host Ports', hostPorts should be disallowed, or at minimum restricted to a known list.

kubernetes_controls.name: Access to host process
kubernetes_controls.description: Windows hostprocess container permits processes in the pod to access the host's network interfaces and IP addresses

kubernetes_controls.name: All container images must start with a GCR domain
kubernetes_controls.description: Containers should only use images from trusted GCR registries.

kubernetes_controls.name: All container images must start with an ECR domain
kubernetes_controls.description: Containers should only use images from trusted registries.

kubernetes_controls.name: All container images must start with the *.azurecr.io domain
kubernetes_controls.description: Containers should only use images from trusted registries.

kubernetes_controls.name: Anonymous user access binding
kubernetes_controls.description: Binding to anonymous user to any clusterrole or role is a security risk

kubernetes_controls.name: Can elevate its own privileges
kubernetes_controls.description: A program inside the container can elevate its own privileges and run as root, which might give the program control over the container and node.

kubernetes_controls.name: ConfigMap with secrets
kubernetes_controls.description: Storing secrets in configMaps is unsafe

kubernetes_controls.name: ConfigMap with sensitive content
kubernetes_controls.description: Storing sensitive content such as usernames and email addresses in configMaps is unsafe

kubernetes_controls.name: Container images from public registries used
kubernetes_controls.description: Container images must not start with an empty prefix or a defined public registry domain.

kubernetes_controls.name: CPU not limited
kubernetes_controls.description: Enforcing CPU limits prevents DoS via resource exhaustion.

kubernetes_controls.name: CPU requests not specified
kubernetes_controls.description: When containers have resource requests specified, the scheduler can make better decisions about which nodes to place pods on, and how to deal with resource contention.

kubernetes_controls.name: Default capabilities: some containers do not drop all
kubernetes_controls.description: The container should drop all default capabilities and add only those that are needed for its execution.

kubernetes_controls.name: Default capabilities: some containers do not drop any
kubernetes_controls.description: Security best practices require containers to run with minimal required capabilities.

kubernetes_controls.name: Default security context configured
kubernetes_controls.description: Security context controls the allocation of security parameters for the pod/container/volume, ensuring the appropriate level of protection. Relying on default security context may expose vulnerabilities to potential attacks that rely on privileged access.

kubernetes_controls.name: Delete pod logs
kubernetes_controls.description: Used to cover attacker’s tracks, but most clusters ship logs quickly off-cluster.

kubernetes_controls.name: Exec into Pods
kubernetes_controls.description: The ability to exec into a container with privileged access to the host or with an attached SA with higher RBAC permissions is a common escalation path to cluster-admin.

kubernetes_controls.name: hostPath volume mounted with docker.sock
kubernetes_controls.description: Mounting docker.sock from the host can give the container full root access to the host.

kubernetes_controls.name: hostPath volumes mounted
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard 'HostPath Volumes', HostPath volumes must be forbidden.

kubernetes_controls.name: Image tag ":latest" used
kubernetes_controls.description: It is best to avoid using the ':latest' image tag when deploying containers in production. Doing so makes it hard to track which version of the image is running, and hard to roll back the version.

kubernetes_controls.name: Kubernetes resource with disallowed volumes mounted
kubernetes_controls.description: HostPath present many security risks and as a security practice it is better to avoid critical host paths mounts.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage all resources
kubernetes_controls.description: Full control of the cluster resources, and therefore also “root” on all nodes where workloads can run and has access to all pods, secrets, and data.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage all resources at the namespace
kubernetes_controls.description: Full control of the resources within a namespace.  In some cluster configurations, this is excessive. In others, this is normal (a gitops deployment operator like flux)

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage configmaps
kubernetes_controls.description: Some workloads leverage configmaps to store sensitive data or configuration parameters that affect runtime behavior that can be modified by an attacker or combined with another issue to potentially lead to compromise.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage EKS IAM Auth ConfigMap
kubernetes_controls.description: Ability to add AWS IAM to RBAC bindings via special EKS configmap.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage Kubernetes networking
kubernetes_controls.description: The ability to control which pods get service traffic directed to them allows for interception attacks. Controlling network policy allows for bypassing lateral movement restrictions.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage Kubernetes RBAC resources
kubernetes_controls.description: An effective level of access equivalent to cluster-admin.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage Kubernetes workloads and pods
kubernetes_controls.description: Depending on the policies enforced by the admission controller, this permission ranges from the ability to steal compute (crypto) by running workloads or allowing for creating workloads that escape to the node as root and escalation to cluster-admin.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage namespace secrets
kubernetes_controls.description: Viewing secrets at the namespace scope can lead to escalation if another service account in that namespace has a higher privileged rolebinding or clusterrolebinding bound.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage secrets
kubernetes_controls.description: Viewing secrets at the cluster-scope is akin to cluster-admin in most clusters as there are typically at least one service accounts (their token stored in a secret) bound to cluster-admin directly or a role/clusterrole that gives similar permissions.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manages /etc/hosts
kubernetes_controls.description: Managing /etc/hosts aliases can prevent the container engine from modifying the file after a pod’s containers have already been started.

kubernetes_controls.name: Manage webhookconfigurations
kubernetes_controls.description: Webhooks can silently intercept or actively mutate/block resources as they are being created or updated. This includes secrets and pod specs.

kubernetes_controls.name: Memory not limited
kubernetes_controls.description: Enforcing memory limits prevents DoS via resource exhaustion.

kubernetes_controls.name: Memory requests not specified
kubernetes_controls.description: When containers have memory requests specified, the scheduler can make better decisions about which nodes to place pods on, and how to deal with resource contention.

kubernetes_controls.name: NET_RAW capability added
kubernetes_controls.description: The NET_RAW capability grants attackers the ability to eavesdrop on network traffic or generate IP traffic with falsified source addresses, posing serious security risks.

kubernetes_controls.name: Non-core volume types used.
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard 'Volume types', non-core volume types must not be used.

kubernetes_controls.name: Non-default /proc masks set
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard '/proc Mount Type', the default /proc masks are set up to reduce attack surface, and should be required.

kubernetes_controls.name: Prevent binding to privileged ports
kubernetes_controls.description: The ports which are lower than 1024 receive and transmit various sensitive and privileged data. Allowing containers to use them can bring serious implications.

kubernetes_controls.name: Privileged
kubernetes_controls.description: Privileged containers share namespaces with the host system and do not offer any security. They should be used exclusively for system containers that require high privileges.

kubernetes_controls.name: PSS Restricted Mode
kubernetes_controls.description: Policy to enforce PSS.

kubernetes_controls.name: Root file system is not read-only
kubernetes_controls.description: An immutable root file system prevents applications from writing to their local disk. This can limit intrusions, as attackers will not be able to tamper with the file system or write foreign executables to disk.

kubernetes_controls.name: Runs as root user
kubernetes_controls.description: Force the running image to run as a non-root user to ensure least privileges.

kubernetes_controls.name: Runs with GID <= 10000
kubernetes_controls.description: Force the container to run with group ID > 10000 to avoid conflicts with the host’s user table.

kubernetes_controls.name: Runs with UID <= 10000
kubernetes_controls.description: Force the container to run with user ID > 10000 to avoid conflicts with the host’s user table.

kubernetes_controls.name: Runtime/Default AppArmor profile not set
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard 'AppArmor', the AppArmor key must be set to the runtime/default profile or to be undefined.

kubernetes_controls.name: Runtime/Default Seccomp profile not set
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard 'Seccomp', the RuntimeDefault seccomp profile must be required, or allow specific additional profiles.

kubernetes_controls.name: Seccomp policies disabled
kubernetes_controls.description: A program inside the container can bypass Seccomp protection policies.

kubernetes_controls.name: SELinux custom options set
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard 'SElinux', setting custom SELinux options should be disallowed.

kubernetes_controls.name: Service with External IP
kubernetes_controls.description: Services with external IP addresses allows direct access from the internet and might expose risk for CVE-2020-8554

kubernetes_controls.name: Specific capabilities added
kubernetes_controls.description: According to pod security standard 'Capabilities', capabilities beyond the default set must not be added.

kubernetes_controls.name: SYS_ADMIN capability added
kubernetes_controls.description: SYS_ADMIN gives the processes running inside the container privileges that are equivalent to root.

kubernetes_controls.name: SYS_MODULE capability added
kubernetes_controls.description: The SYS_MODULE capability grants attackers the ability to install and remove kernel modules, posing serious security risks.

kubernetes_controls.name: Unsafe sysctl options set
kubernetes_controls.description: Sysctls can disable security mechanisms or affect all containers on a host, and should be disallowed except for an allowed 'safe' subset. A sysctl is considered safe if it is namespaced in the container or the pod, and is isolated from other pods and processes on the same node.

kubernetes_controls.name: User with admin access
kubernetes_controls.description: Either cluster-admin or those granted powerful permissions.

kubernetes_controls.name: Workloads in the default namespace
kubernetes_controls.description: Checks whether a workload is running in the default namespace.
